required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Day/Night Regimen With Provox Life Heat and Moisture Exchangers
clinical_study.official_title: Changes in Pulmonary Outcomes as a Result of Implementing a Day and Night Regimen With Heat and Moisture Exchangers (HMEs) and Their Attachments

brief_summary.textblock:
Purpose and Aim: This research is about patients who have had a total laryngectomy, trialing a new range of Heat and Moisture Exchangers (HMEs) - referred to as the "Provox Life™ range of HMEs". The main purpose of this study is to find out if participants experience any differences in the amount of coughing and mucus problems when using the new range of Provox Life™ HMEs (and attachment devices) following an optimal Day/Night regimen. The study is sponsored by Atos Medical.
Study Design: Participants will use the new Provox Life™ HME range and their attachments during two (2) observation phases (Phase 1, Phase 2). In Phase 1 (6 week study phase), participants will use the new Provox Life™ HMEs in a similar way as they currently use their existing HME devices. In the Phase 2 (6 week study phase), they will use the Provox Life™ HME devices following an optimal Day/Night regimen - with the aim to achieve the best possible humidification at all times. Prior to each study phase, participants will meet with their speech pathologist to learn about the new devices and how to use them. Once comfortable using them they will commence each observation phase.
Data Collection: Experiences using their existing HMEs (prior to study) and then using the new HMEs in Phase 1 and Phase 2 will be collected via a series of questionnaires. These will be completed 5 times in total - at baseline before Phase 1 starts, and then at both week 2 and week 6 of Phase 1 and 2. Questionnaires relate to their use of the HMEs, coughing and mucus problems, skin integrity, overall experiences of using the new devices and any impacts on sleep and quality of life. Participants will complete some of the questionnaires at home (approx. 30mins) and the others during an interview session with one of the study team (approx. 30mins). The interview session can be conducted via telephone, videoconferencing or in person - depending on the patients preferences and any COVID restrictions.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Multi-center, prospective, two-phase clinical study. The end of Phase 1 serves as the baseline for Phase 2.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in COUS score of CASA-Q
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from End of Phase 1 (week 6) to End of Phase 2 (week 12)
primary_outcome.description: Cough Symptoms (COUS) assessed with validated Coughing and Sputum Assessment Questionnaire (CASA-Q). Score between 0 and 100, with higher scores meaning less symptoms and less impact.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from End of Phase 1 (week 6) to End of Phase 2 (week 12)
primary_outcome.description: Cough Impact (COUI) assessed with validated Coughing and Sputum Assessment Questionnaire (CASA-Q). Score between 0 and 100, with higher scores meaning less symptoms and less impact.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in SPUS score of CASA-Q
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Sputum Symptoms (SPUS) domains of the CASA-Q. Score between 0 and 100, with higher scores meaning less symptoms and less impact.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in SPUI score of CASA-Q
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Sputum Impact (SPUI) domains of the CASA-Q. Score between 0 and 100, with higher scores meaning less symptoms and less impact.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in COUS scores of CASA-Q
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks), and Phase 2 (2 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Cough Symptoms (COUS) assessed with validated Coughing and Sputum Assessment Questionnaire (CASA-Q). Score between 0 and 100, with higher scores meaning less symptoms and less impact.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in COUI scores of CASA-Q
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks), and Phase 2 (2 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: CCough Impact (COUI) assessed with validated Coughing and Sputum Assessment Questionnaire (CASA-Q). Score between 0 and 100, with higher scores meaning less symptoms and less impact.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of forced mucus expectorations per 24 hours
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Patient reported, recorded by tally sheeting

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of involuntary coughs per 24 hours
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Patient reported, recorded by tally sheeting

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: patient reported, the descriptive system assesses health in five dimensions, from which a health state index score is calculated, range from 0 to 1, with higher scores indicatinghigher health utility

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Patient reported to assess sleep quality. Score between 0 and 20, with higher score the more sleep disturbances

secondary_outcome.measure: Questionnaire to assess Shortness of Breath
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)

secondary_outcome.measure: Questionnaire to adjustment to Day/Night regimen
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Study specific questionnaire to describe patients adjustment to Day/Night regimen

secondary_outcome.measure: Consumption of medical devices (Number of devices used)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of devices used, by use of patient diary recoding number of devices used

secondary_outcome.measure: Study-specific questionnaire to assess number of complications and medical treatments
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Study specific questionnaire to record complications and consumption of medications, diagnostics, treatment, medical care, medical transportation, sick leave

secondary_outcome.measure: Study-specific questionnaire to assess patients satisfaction
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Phase 1 (2 weeks, 6 weeks), Phase 2 (2 weeks, 6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: patient satisfaction with devices and regimen

arm_group.description: Phase 1: Provox Life™. Like-for-like transition from Provox (or other brand) to Provox Life™ under guidance from Speech Pathologist who will assess when the participant is ready to commence the 6 week study observation period. Phase 2: Provox Life™ with Day/Night regimen. Establishment of optimal day/night routine under guidance of Speech Pathologist who will assess when the participant is ready to commence the 6 week observation period.

intervention.description: Phase 1: Like for like transition, Phase 2: Provox Life day/night regimen

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Total laryngectomy, irrespective of pharynx reconstruction method
- 18 years or older
- HME user
- Longer than 3 months after total laryngectomy
- Longer than 6 weeks after postoperative radiotherapy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Current day/night routine with Provox Luna
- Daily use of Provox Micron HMEF
- Medical problems prohibiting the use of HME
- Active recurrent or metastatic disease (medical deterioration)
- Recent pulmonary infections/unstable pulmonary condition
- Reduced mobility of arms and/or hands, unable to insert or remove an HME
- Unable to understand the Participant Information and/or unable to give Informed Consent
- Insufficient cognitive ability to manage HME or adhesive use

overall_official.affiliation: Centre for functioning and Health Research, Metro South Hospital and Health Service
